title.textEnglish: Asymptotic stability of a nonlinear wave for the compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg equations in the half space

abstract.textEnglish: This paper is concerned with the time-asymptotic stability of a nonlinear wave for the outflow problem of the isentropic compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg equations in the half space. Under some suitable assumptions on the spatial-asymptotic states and boundary data, the time-asymptotic profile is a nonlinear wave which is the superposition of a stationary solution and a rarefaction wave. Employing the <inline-formula id="IEq1"> <mml:math> <mml:mi>L</mml:mi> <mml:mn>2</mml:mn> </mml:math> <tex-math id="IEq1_TeX">\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$L^{2}$$\end{document}</tex-math> </inline-formula>-energy method and the decay (in both time and space variables) estimates of each component of the nonlinear wave, we prove that this nonlinear wave is time asymptotically stable under a small initial perturbation.

fulltext.body:
Introduction

In this paper, we are interested in the following isentropic compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg equation: ρ t + ( ρ u ) x = 0 , ( ρ u ) t + ( ρ u 2 + p ( ρ ) ) x = μ u xx + κ ρ ρ xxx . \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} \left\{ \begin{array}{l} {\rho _{t}+(\rho u)_{x}=0,} \\ {(\rho u)_{t}+(\rho u^{2}+p(\rho ))_{x}=\mu u_{xx}+\kappa \rho \rho _{xxx}}. \end{array}\right. \end{aligned}$$\end{document} Here, the time and space variables are t > 0 \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$t>0$$\end{document} and x ∈ R + : = x ∈ R : x > 0 \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$x\in {\mathbb {R}}^+:= \left\{ x\in {\mathbb {R}}: x> 0\right\} $$\end{document} , respectively. ρ , u \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\rho ,u$$\end{document} are unknown functions in t and x, which stand for the density and the velocity, respectively. The function p ( ρ ) \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$p(\rho )$$\end{document} is the pressure defined by p ( ρ ) = K ρ γ \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ p(\rho ) = K\rho ^\gamma $$\end{document} , where K > 0 \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$K>0$$\end{document} and γ ≥ 1 \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\gamma \ge 1$$\end{document} are the gas constants. The positive constants μ , κ \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\mu , \kappa $$\end{document} denote, respectively, the viscosity coefficient and the capillary coefficient, and κ \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$ \kappa $$\end{document} is also called Weber number.

The compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg equation ( 1.1) can govern the motion of compressible fluids such as liquid vapor mixtures, which is the compressible fluids endowed with internal capillarity. Capillary phenomena are ubiquitous, complex and diverse in nature and they are also found in various industrial processes that ranging from off-shore engineering to automotive (e.g., carburant injection) and chemical engineering. The formulation of the theory of capillary with diffusive interface can be traced back to the work of Van de Waals [ 51] and Korteweg [ 29] more than one century ago, and was actually derived in its modern form in the 1980s using the second gradient theory, see for instance [ 11]. Heida and Málek [ 19] also derived ( 1.1) by the entropy production method which does not require to introduce any new or non-standard concepts such as multipolarity or interstitial working which are used in [ 11]. One can see easily that when κ = 0 \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\kappa =0$$\end{document} , system ( 1.1) is reduced to the classical Navier–Stokes equations for compressible fluids.

In recent years, there have been a great number of mathematical studies on the compressible Naviver-Stokes-Korteweg equations. In what follows, let us first focus on the large-time behavior of solutions to the isentropic compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg equations, which is related to our interest. When the initial perturbation of the non-vacuum constant states is small, Wang and Tan [ 52], Tan et al. [ 49], and Tan and Wang [ 48] established the optimal time decay rates of the global classical/strong solutions for the isentropic compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg equations. Tan and Zhang [ 50] further obtained the time decay rates of more derivatives of solutions when the initial perturbation is in the negative Sobolev H - s ( R 3 ) \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$H^{-s}({\mathbb {R}}^3)$$\end{document} with 0 ≤ s < 3 / 2 \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$0\le s < 3/2$$\end{document} . Kobayashi and Tsuda [ 28] obtained the global existence and time decay rates of solutions to the compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg system under critical condition. Moreover, for the initial value problem of the isentropic compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg system, the large-time behavior around nonlinear wave patterns such as the stationary wave, the contact discontinuity wave and the rarefaction wave has been studied. More precisely, the stability of stationary solutions of the multi-dimensional isentropic compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg equations was studied by Li [ 35], and Wang and Wang [ 53] in the case with a external force, under the assumption that the states at far fields ± ∞ \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\pm \infty $$\end{document} are equal. Later, Chen [ 3] and Li and Luo [ 36] discussed asymptotic stability of the rarefaction waves for the one-dimensional compressible fluid models of Korteweg type with different states at far fields. Chen, et al. [ 4] also showed asymptotic stability of the rarefaction waves for the one-dimensional compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg system with large initial data. Li and Zhu [ 38] further showed the asymptotic stability of the rarefaction wave with vacuum for the one-dimensional compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg equations. Chen, He and Zhao [ 6] studied the nonlinear stability of traveling wave solutions for the one-dimensional compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg equations.

For the initial-boundary value problem, Tsyganov [ 47] discussed the global existence and time-asymptotic behavior of weak solutions for an isothermal model with the viscosity coefficient μ ( ρ ) ≡ 1 \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\mu (\rho )\equiv 1$$\end{document} , the capillarity coefficient κ ( ρ ) = ρ - 5 \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\kappa (\rho )={\rho ^{-5}}$$\end{document} and large initial data on the interval [0, 1]. The global existence and exponential decay of strong solutions with small initial data to the Korteweg system in a bounded domain of R n \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$${\mathbb {R}}^n$$\end{document} ( n ≥ 1 \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$n\ge 1$$\end{document} ) were obtained by Kotschote in [ 31]. Another interesting and challenging problem is to study the stability of the compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg system in the half space with different gas states at boundary and far field. Recently, Chen, Li and Sheng [ 8] proved the nonlinear stability of viscous shock wave for an impermeable wall problem of the compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg system with constant viscosity and capillarity coefficients and small initial data. Chen and Li [ 7] discussed the time-asymptotic behavior of strong solutions to the initial-boundary value problem of the compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg system with density-dependent viscosity and capillarity on the half-line R + \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$${\mathbb {R}}^+$$\end{document} , and showed the strong solution converges to the rarefaction wave as t → ∞ \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$t\rightarrow \infty $$\end{document} for the impermeable wall problem under large initial perturbation. Hong [ 20] and Li and Zhu [ 39] showed the existence and stability of stationary solution to an outflow problem of the compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg system with constant viscosity and capillarity coefficients, respectively. Li, Tang and Yu [ 37] proved asymptotic stability of rarefaction wave for the outflow problem of the compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg equations in the half space.

Finally, we also mentioned that there are many studies on the local/global existence and uniqueness of solutions to the isentropic compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg equations, we refer to [ 1, 13, 15] and the references therein for the global existence of weak solutions, [ 9, 10, 14, 16, 30] and the references therein for the local and global existence of strong solutions, and [ 17, 18, 22, 23] and the references therein for the local and global existence of smooth solutions.

In this article, we shall investigate the large-time behavior of the solution to an initial boundary value problem for the one-dimensional Navier–Stokes–Korteweg equations ( 1.1) in the half space R + \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$${\mathbb {R}}^+$$\end{document} . Consequently, equations ( 1.1) is imposed with the following initial and boundary conditions: ( ρ , u ) ( 0 , x ) = ( ρ 0 , u 0 ) ( x ) for x > 0 , and inf x ∈ R + ρ 0 ( x ) > 0 , \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \textrm{any}~t\ge 0. \end{aligned}$$\end{document} Here ρ + \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\rho _{+}$$\end{document} , u + \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$u_{+}$$\end{document} and u b \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$u_{b}$$\end{document} are constants satisfying ρ + > 0 \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\rho _{+}>0$$\end{document} . And ρ 0 ( x ) , u 0 ( x ) \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\rho _{0}(x),u_{0}(x)$$\end{document} are given functions.

We are interested in the so-called outflow problem. For this case the boundary data of u is taken as negative value, i.e., u b < 0 . \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} u_{b}<0. \end{aligned}$$\end{document} This means physically that the outflow exists constantly through the wall. Moreover, we also need ρ x ( t , 0 ) = 0 \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\rho _x(t,0)= 0$$\end{document} for the third-order capillary term in ( 1.1). We note that for the case that u b > 0 \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$u_{b}>0$$\end{document} , the situation is different and the corresponding problem is called an inflow problem. In that case, for the well-posedness, one must impose one more boundary condition at x = 0 \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$x=0$$\end{document} , namely we must consider a set of boundary conditions of the form ρ ( t , 0 ) = ρ b , u ( t , 0 ) = u b , ρ x ( t , 0 ) = ρ 1 b , t ≥ 0 \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\begin{aligned} \rho (t,0) = \rho _{b},~ u(t,0) = u_{b},~\rho _x(t,0) =\rho _{1b},~~t\ge 0 \end{aligned}$$\end{document} with ρ b > 0 \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\rho _{b}>0$$\end{document} and u b > 0 \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$u_{b}>0$$\end{document} .

As we know, three basic wave patterns to the system of hyperbolic conservation laws, i.e., shock and rarefaction waves in the genuinely nonlinear characteristic fields, and contact discontinuity in the linearly degenerate fields, govern the large-time behavior of the solutions to the ideal fluid model with the dissipative effects such as the compressible Navier–Stokes equations. There has been a huge number of papers in the literature on the large-time behavior of the solutions to the initial-boundary value problem of the compressible Navier–Stokes equations. In this type of problems, the influence of viscosity is expected to emerge not only in the smoothing effect on discontinuous shock wave but also in the forming of a boundary layer. More precisely, Matsumura and Mei [ 43] considered the stability of viscous shock wave to the one-dimensional Navier–Stokes equations with a Dirichlet boundary condition. Matsumura and Nishihara [ 41] showed global asymptotics toward rarefaction waves for solution of the viscous p-system with boundary effect. Matsumura [ 40] gave, in 2001, a classification of the large-time behavior of the solutions in terms of the far-field states and boundary data. Kawashima, Nishibata and Zhu [ 32] investigated the asymptotic stability of the stationary solution to an outflow problem of the compressible Navier–Stokes equations in the half space. Matsumura and Nishihara [ 42] studied the large-time behavior of solutions to an inflow problem in the half space for a one-dimensional isentropic model system for compressible viscous gas. Huang, Matsumura and Shi [ 26] obtained the nonlinear stability of viscous shock wave and boundary layer solution for an inflow problem of the isentropic compressible Navier–Stokes equations. Recently, there are many references on the large-time behavior of solutions for the full compressible Navier–Stokes equations, the interested reader are referred to [ 24, 25] and the references therein for the impermeable wall problem, [ 12, 21, 24, 44, 45] and the references therein for the inflow problem, and [ 27, 33, 34] and the references therein for the outflow problem.

The main aim of this paper is to investigate the large-time behavior of the solution to the outflow problem ( 1.1)-( 1.3). Motivated by [ 2, 5] and [ 33, 34, 40], we believe that as t → ∞ \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$t\rightarrow \infty $$\end{document} , the solution ( ρ , u ) \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$(\rho ,u)$$\end{document} to the above problem ( 1.1)-( 1.3) is asymptotically described by one of the following waves: a viscous shock wave, a stationary wave, a rarefaction wave or the superposition of a stationary wave and a rarefaction wave, which can be determined by the space-asymptotic conditions ( 1.4) and the boundary data u b \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$u_b$$\end{document} . The stability of a single stationary wave or rarefaction wave has been investigated in [ 20, 37, 39]. In this paper, we are interested particularly in the case that the corresponding time-asymptotic state is the composite wave consisting of a stationary and a rarefaction wave, which is the third one of the series of papers by the authors on the stability of nonlinear waves for the outflow problem of the compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg equations. Remark 1.1

Some remarks on Theorem 1.1 are listed as follows.

Theorem 1.1 shows that the superposition of the stationary wave and the rarefaction wave is time-asymptotically stable when the initial perturbation is small, and both the strength of the boundary layer and the strength of the rarefaction wave are suitably weak. In [ 34], the authors proved the nonlinear stability of the same nonlinear wave for the compressible Navier–Stokes equations under small initial perturbation. Thus Theorem 1.1 can be viewed as a extension of [ 34] to case of compressible flow with internal capillarity.

In Theorem 1.1, the initial data needs to be sufficiently small, thus it is interesting and more challenging to consider the corresponding problem with large initial data, which is left for the future.

In the present article and [ 20, 37, 39], the authors consider only the outflow problem of the one-dimensional compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg equations. However we should mention that the corresponding inflow problem is surely more difficult, thus is more interesting. Finally, it is more attractive to study the same kind of problems for the full compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg system. These are expected to be done in the forthcoming papers.

The outline of the proof of Theorem 1.1 is as follows. Using the arguments and ideas in [ 34], we are going to employ the standard continuation argument which is based on a local existence theorem and some a priori estimates (see Proposition 3.3) to prove this theorem. The key approach is the energy method. We shall point out that compared with the results in [ 34] for the isentropic compressible Navier–Stokes system, it is highly non-trivial, due to the presence of the boundary condition, the complexity of the nonlinear wave which is the superposition of a stationary solution and a rarefaction wave, and the occurrence of the third order dispersion term, in establishing the energy estimates for the compressible Navier–Stokes–Korteweg system. Since the complexity of nonlinear wave and partial dissipation of the boundary condition has been investigated carefully in [ 34], we only need to focus on the Korteweg stress term. Consequently, compared to the case of compressible Navier–Stokes equations [ 34], the main novelties of the present paper are as follows:

First, due to the effect of Korteweg tensor, there are some additional nonlinear terms in the energy-type estimates, which represent the interactions between the wave patterns (the stationary wave and/or the smoothed rarefaction wave) and the solution itself, such as ∫ 0 ∞ ρ xxx r ψ d x \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\int \limits _0^\infty \rho _{xxx}^r\psi dx$$\end{document} , ∫ 0 ∞ ρ ~ xxx r ( ρ r - ρ ∗ ) ψ d x \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\int \limits _0^\infty \tilde{\rho }_{xxx}^r(\rho ^r-\rho _*)\psi dx$$\end{document} , ∫ 0 ∞ ρ ~ xxx r ( ρ r - ρ ∗ ) φ x d x \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\int \limits _0^\infty \tilde{\rho }_{xxx}^r(\rho ^r-\rho _*)\varphi _xdx$$\end{document} and ∫ 0 ∞ ρ ~ xxx ρ x r φ xx d x \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\int \limits _0^\infty \tilde{\rho }_{xxx}\rho _x^r\varphi _{xx}dx$$\end{document} , etc. We deal with these nonlinear terms by the decay properties of the stationary wave and the smoothed rarefaction wave in both time and space variables, and some delicate analysis (see the proof of ( 4.11), ( 4.28) ( 4.40), ( 4.42), ( 4.50) for details).

The remaining part of this paper unfolds as follows: In Sect. 2, we restate the pointwise estimates of the stationary solution which have been derived in [ 39]. Next, for reader’s convenience, we recall the properties of the smoothed rarefaction waves which have been constructed in [ 7, 26, 41]. In Sect. 3, the original problem is reformulated and our main theorem is also restated. Section 4 is devoted to establishing the a priori estimates for the reformulated problem. Finally, in Sect. 5, we present the proof of our main Theorem 1.1.

The proof of Theorem <xref ref-type="" rid="FPar1">1.1</xref>

This section is concerned with the proof of our main theorem. The global existence of solutions to the initial boundary value problem ( 1.1)-( 1.3) can be obtained by employing the standard continuation argument which is based on the local existence result Proposition 3.1 and the a priori estimates stated in Proposition 3.2. Therefore, to complete the proof of Theorem 1.1, we need only to investigate the large-time behavior of the solution ( ρ , u ) ( t , x ) \documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$(\rho ,u)(t,x)$$\end{document} to the initial boundary value problem ( 1.1)-( 1.3) as time tends to infinity.

The completion of the proof of Theorem 1.1. Based upon the energy estimates derived in the previous sections, we will complete the proof of Theorem 1.1.
